newsitem.title: DUBAI: Saudi Arabia fines copyright violators.
newsitem.headline: Saudi Arabia fines copyright violators.

text.p: Saudi Arabia has imposed fines and temporarily closed outlets of copyright violators in the kingdom in the last nine months to the end of January as part of its crack down on piracy, newspapers reported on Monday.

"Monitors of the ministry of information have fined owners of shops violating copyright to the tune of 980,000 riyals ($261,000) during a nine-month period beginning in May," the English language Arab News said.
"In addition to fines, they have ordered temporary closures of 160 shops," it added.
The papers said the fines ranged between 1,000 and 20,000 riyals while the closure period ranged between seven to 60 days.

The Washington-based Business Software Alliance-- which groups leading U.S. software firms-- estimates software makers lost around $100 million to piracy in 1995 in Saudi Arabia, where analysts estimate nine out 10 programmes are unlicensed.
Saudi authorities in December raided several outlets of pirated software, seizing programmes worth about $2 million.

Saudi Arabia has said it was making a major effort to adapt to the World Trade Organisation's standards and norms for intellectual property rights, an important condition for the kingdom's push to join the world trade body.
